title: Jeremiah Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 23.

questions.question: Who does the LORD pronounce woe upon in Jeremiah 23:1?
options: Pastors that destroy and scatter the sheep
questions.correctAnswer: Pastors that destroy and scatter the sheep
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:1 states woe unto the pastors that destroy and scatter the sheep of God's pasture.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 23:3, what will the LORD do with the remnant of His flock?
options: Gather them from all countries and bring them to their folds
questions.correctAnswer: Gather them from all countries and bring them to their folds
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:3 says the LORD will gather the remnant of His flock out of all countries and bring them again to their folds.

questions.question: Who will the LORD raise up as a righteous Branch according to Jeremiah 23:5?
questions.correctAnswer: David's descendant
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:5 mentions the LORD will raise unto David a righteous Branch who will reign and prosper.

questions.question: What name will the King raised from David be called in Jeremiah 23:6?
questions.correctAnswer: THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:6 states that the King shall be called THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 23:7, what will people no longer say?
options: The LORD liveth, which brought up the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD liveth, which brought up the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:7 says that the days come when they shall no more say the LORD liveth who brought up Israel out of Egypt.

questions.question: What causes Jeremiah's heart to be broken and his bones to shake in Jeremiah 23:9?
options: The words of the LORD's holiness and because of the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The words of the LORD's holiness and because of the prophets
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:9 explains that Jeremiah's heart is broken because of the prophets and the words of the LORD's holiness.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 23:11, where has the LORD found the wickedness of the prophets and priests?
questions.correctAnswer: In His house
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:11 states the LORD has found their wickedness in His house.

questions.question: What will happen to the prophets because of their folly, according to Jeremiah 23:12?
options: They shall be driven on slippery ways in darkness and fall
They will be praised among the people
They will receive a crown of glory
They will be protected by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be driven on slippery ways in darkness and fall
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:12 says their way will be as slippery ways in darkness; they shall be driven and fall therein.

questions.question: What horrible thing did the LORD see in the prophets of Jerusalem in Jeremiah 23:14?
options: They commit adultery and walk in lies
They build altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They commit adultery and walk in lies
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:14 describes the prophets of Jerusalem committing adultery and walking in lies.

questions.question: What does the LORD say He will feed the false prophets in Jeremiah 23:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Wormwood and water of gall
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:15 states the LORD will feed them with wormwood and make them drink the water of gall.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 23:21 states that the LORD sent the false prophets but they did not obey Him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:21 says the LORD did not send the prophets, yet they ran and prophesied on their own.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 23:23 affirms that the LORD is both a God at hand and a God afar off.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:23 asks rhetorically if God is at hand and not afar off, affirming both.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 23:32 says the false prophets will profit the people greatly.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:32 states the false prophets shall not profit this people at all.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Jeremiah 23:29: 'Is not my word like as a ______? saith the LORD; and like a hammer that breaketh the rock in pieces?'
questions.correctAnswer: fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:29 compares God's word to a fire and a hammer that breaks rock.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Jeremiah 23:24: 'Can any hide himself in secret places that I shall not see him? saith the LORD. Do not I fill ______ and earth?'
questions.correctAnswer: heaven
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:24 says the LORD fills heaven and earth and sees all.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement because their spiritual leaders seem unfaithful. Based on Jeremiah 23, what biblical truth would you share about God's care for His people?
options: God will gather and restore His scattered flock and provide faithful shepherds.
God will leave the people without guidance until they repent.
God will punish the people for following false prophets.
God only cares about the righteous and ignores the rest.
questions.correctAnswer: God will gather and restore His scattered flock and provide faithful shepherds.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:1-4 teaches that though pastors may scatter the sheep, the LORD promises to gather the remnant and set up shepherds who will feed and care for them, assuring safety and provision.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 23 teach us about trusting God's promises regarding leadership and justice?
options: God will raise a righteous Branch from David who will reign with justice and bring safety.
God will leave leadership to human wisdom without intervention.
God will punish all kings equally without raising a new ruler.
questions.correctAnswer: God will raise a righteous Branch from David who will reign with justice and bring safety.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:5-6 promises that a righteous King will come from David's line who will execute judgment and bring salvation and safety to Judah and Israel.

questions.question: A believer feels confused because some prophets promise peace despite evident wickedness around. What warning does Jeremiah 23 give about such false prophets?
options: They speak from their own hearts and not from the LORD, giving vain hope.
They faithfully warn the people of coming judgment.
They are sent directly by God to comfort the people.
questions.correctAnswer: They speak from their own hearts and not from the LORD, giving vain hope.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:16-17 explains that false prophets proclaim peace and safety based on their own imaginations rather than God's word, leading people astray.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 23 emphasize the importance of integrity in proclaiming God’s word?
options: Prophets must faithfully speak God's word, not dreams or lies.
Prophets can share whatever visions they receive without accountability.
Prophets are free to modify God's word for easier acceptance.
Prophets should avoid delivering difficult messages.
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets must faithfully speak God's word, not dreams or lies.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:27-28 instructs that true prophets speak the LORD's word faithfully, contrasting it with false dreams and deceitful messages.

questions.question: In the context of church life and fellowship, what warning does Jeremiah 23 give about leaders who misuse their authority?
options: Woe to those pastors who destroy and scatter the flock without caring for them.
Leaders should always be forgiven regardless of their actions.
It is acceptable to neglect the flock if the leaders are under pressure.
Only the people are responsible for their spiritual health.
questions.correctAnswer: Woe to those pastors who destroy and scatter the flock without caring for them.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:1-2 warns strongly against pastors who fail to care for God's people, scattering them and not visiting them, and promises judgment for their deeds.

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation to follow leaders who promise peace but lead to sin. Based on Jeremiah 23, what biblical principle should guide them?
options: Discern God's word carefully and reject prophets who prophesy lies or false peace.
Trust every prophetic word if it sounds comforting.
Follow leaders who are popular regardless of their message.
Avoid all prophecy since it is confusing.
questions.correctAnswer: Discern God's word carefully and reject prophets who prophesy lies or false peace.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:21-22, 32 instructs believers not to trust prophets who speak without God's commission and lead people astray with lies and false dreams.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 23 teach about God's presence and accountability in everyday life and work?
options: God is everywhere and sees all actions, so we must live with integrity.
God only watches over some people.
God is distant and unaware of daily conduct.
Accountability is only to church leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: God is everywhere and sees all actions, so we must live with integrity.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:23-24 declares that God is both near and far, filling heaven and earth, and nothing is hidden from Him, highlighting the call to honesty and integrity.

questions.question: How can Jeremiah 23 encourage believers to persevere through trials involving false teachers?
options: God’s anger will ultimately execute justice, and His word is powerful like a hammer.
False teachers will always succeed and should be followed.
Believers should ignore God's word during trials.
Trials are a sign God has abandoned His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger will ultimately execute justice, and His word is powerful like a hammer.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:19-20, 29 assures that God’s judgment will come in due time and His word is powerful like fire and hammer to break down opposition.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is highlighted by Jeremiah 23’s description of the consequences for those who misuse God's word?
options: Honesty in speech and faithfulness to God's message.
Tolerance of all teachings regardless of truth.
questions.correctAnswer: Honesty in speech and faithfulness to God's message.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:30-32 shows God’s opposition to those who steal or falsely use His words, emphasizing the importance of honest, faithful communication of Scripture.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness towards a brother who has sinned. How might Jeremiah 23's teaching on God’s justice and mercy encourage forgiveness?
options: God promises to restore the remnant and establish righteous leadership, showing His mercy.
Forgiveness is only for the perfect.
God’s justice is too harsh for mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to restore the remnant and establish righteous leadership, showing His mercy.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:3-6 reveals God's plan to gather His people and raise a righteous King, indicating His mercy and desire for restoration even after judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 23 teaches that God will forget and forsake those who persist in perverting His words and burdens.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:39 clearly states that God will utterly forget and forsake those who pervert His words and the city given to them.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 23 encourages believers to rely on the dreams and visions of all prophets as equally valid.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:27-28 warns that false prophets use dreams to deceive and that only the faithful speaking of God's word should be trusted.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 23 says, "Is not my word like as a _______, and like a hammer that breaketh the rock in pieces?"
questions.correctAnswer: fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:29 compares God's word to fire and a hammer, emphasizing its power to break and purify.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 23 highlight the role of spiritual leaders in guiding others toward repentance and obedience?
options: Leaders must stand in God's counsel and turn people from evil ways.
Leaders should avoid confronting sin to maintain peace.
Leaders have no responsibility for the people's actions.
Leaders should only focus on rituals, not moral guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must stand in God's counsel and turn people from evil ways.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:22 stresses that true prophets who stand in God's counsel would cause His people to turn from evil and avoid their sinful ways.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 23 teach about the effects of unfaithful prophets on the community?
options: They cause the people to err, strengthen evildoers, and bring spiritual ruin like Sodom and Gomorrah.
They bring peace and unity to the community.
They have little effect on the spiritual health of the people.
They are always corrected by faithful priests.
questions.correctAnswer: They cause the people to err, strengthen evildoers, and bring spiritual ruin like Sodom and Gomorrah.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:13-15 describes unfaithful prophets leading Israel into error and sin, comparing them to the corrupt cities of Sodom and Gomorrah.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 23.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 23:5, the "righteous Branch" raised unto David is a foreshadowing of which New Testament figure?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:5 speaks of a righteous Branch from David who will reign and execute justice, a clear Messianic prophecy fulfilled in Jesus Christ, the descendant of David.

questions.question: The phrase "THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS" in Jeremiah 23:6 is significant in biblical theology because it emphasizes what theological concept?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine justification
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:6 names the Messianic figure as 'THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS,' highlighting God's provision of righteousness to His people, a key theme in both Old and New Testament justification theology.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 23:3-4 employ shepherd imagery to contribute to the chapter’s overall message?
options: It contrasts false leaders with God’s appointed shepherds
It describes literal shepherds of sheep
It foretells the destruction of the flock
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts false leaders with God’s appointed shepherds
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 contrast the scattering by false shepherds with God’s promise to gather and appoint faithful shepherds, symbolizing restoration and righteous leadership.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominent in Jeremiah 23:29 when God’s word is compared to 'a fire' and 'a hammer that breaketh the rock in pieces'?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:29 uses similes comparing God's word to fire and a hammer, illustrating its power to purify and break hardness, emphasizing divine authority.

questions.question: Jeremiah 23:7-8 shifts the focus from the Exodus to a future regathering. What is the significance of this shift in Israel’s history?
options: It anticipates a new exodus from Babylonian exile
It refers only to spiritual restoration
It predicts the conquest of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates a new exodus from Babylonian exile
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:7-8 contrasts the original Exodus with a coming regathering 'from the north country,' pointing to the return of exiles, a key theme in post-exilic restoration.

questions.question: The condemnation of prophets in Jeremiah 23:16-17 reflects what issue regarding prophetic speech in ancient Israel?
options: False prophecy motivated by personal desires
questions.correctAnswer: False prophecy motivated by personal desires
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:16-17 condemns prophets who speak from their own hearts and provide false peace, highlighting the problem of self-serving false prophecy.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 23:21-22, what was the intended role of true prophets in Israel?
options: To turn the people from evil ways
questions.correctAnswer: To turn the people from evil ways
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:21-22 states that true prophets stand in God's counsel and lead people to repentance, emphasizing their role in moral reformation.

questions.question: Jeremiah 23:23-24 contains a rhetorical question about God’s presence. What theological truth does this affirm about God?
options: God is limited to the temple
God is indifferent to human actions
questions.correctAnswer: God is omnipresent
questions.explanation: Verses 23-24 affirm God's omnipresence, stating He is both near and far and sees all things, countering claims that He is distant or unaware.

questions.question: In the context of Jeremiah 23, what is the significance of the phrase 'The burden of the LORD' as used in verses 33-38?
options: It refers to true prophetic messages from God
It is a term for musical songs
It is a phrase used by false prophets to mislead
questions.correctAnswer: It is a phrase used by false prophets to mislead
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:33-38 criticizes misuse of the phrase 'The burden of the LORD' by false prophets who perverted God's word, leading to judgment.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 23:13-14 portray the prophets of Samaria and Jerusalem in terms of their moral and spiritual conduct?
options: They are depicted as corrupt and leading people astray
They are praised for their faithfulness
They are foreign priests from Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They are depicted as corrupt and leading people astray
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 describe prophets engaging in folly, adultery, and lies, equating them to the wickedness of Sodom and Gomorrah, indicating deep corruption.

questions.question: Jeremiah 23:15 uses the metaphors 'wormwood' and 'water of gall' to describe what consequence for false prophets?
questions.correctAnswer: Bitterness and judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states that God will feed false prophets with wormwood and make them drink gall, metaphors for severe bitterness and divine judgment.

questions.question: The imagery of a whirlwind in Jeremiah 23:19-20 is an example of what literary and theological device?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment symbol
questions.explanation: In verses 19-20, the whirlwind symbolizes God's fierce and inescapable judgment upon the wicked, a common prophetic metaphor.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 23:1-2 condemns the pastors for neglecting and scattering the sheep, reflecting a theme of leadership accountability in Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 explicitly condemn pastors who destroy and scatter the flock, highlighting the theme of leaders' responsibility for God's people.

questions.question: Jeremiah 23:27 mentions that the prophets cause people to forget God's name as their fathers forgot it for Baal. What does this imply about the historical context?
options: Syncretism and idolatry were ongoing issues
Baal worship was eradicated before Jeremiah
The prophets promoted exclusive Yahweh worship
questions.correctAnswer: Syncretism and idolatry were ongoing issues
questions.explanation: Verse 27 connects false prophecy to historical apostasy, indicating that syncretism with Baal worship persisted, undermining true faith.

questions.question: Jeremiah 23:30-32 contains a series of "I am against" statements by the LORD. What rhetorical function do these serve?
questions.correctAnswer: Emphatic denunciation of false prophets
questions.explanation: Verses 30-32 use repeated "I am against" phrases to strongly denounce false prophets who steal words and prophesy lies, underlining God's judgment.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 23, what is the LORD's judgment against the pastors who destroy and scatter His flock?
options: He will visit upon them the evil of their doings
He will reward them with a crown of righteousness
He will send them to be kings over Israel
He will restore them to their former positions
questions.correctAnswer: He will visit upon them the evil of their doings
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:1-2 warns that the pastors who scatter the sheep will face the LORD's judgment because they failed to care for His people. This is consistent with Ezekiel 34:2-10 where God condemns the false shepherds, and with Matthew 25:31-46 where shepherd imagery is used to distinguish care from neglect.

questions.question: What promise does God make regarding the remnant of His flock in Jeremiah 23?
options: He will gather them from all countries and bring them to their folds
He will abandon them to their enemies
He will send them into exile forever
He will destroy them for their disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: He will gather them from all countries and bring them to their folds
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:3 states God's promise to regather the scattered remnant and bring them back to safety, echoing the covenant faithfulness seen in Deuteronomy 30:3 and Isaiah 11:11-12 where God restores His people from exile.

questions.question: Who does God say He will raise up as a righteous Branch and King in Jeremiah 23?
questions.correctAnswer: Unto David
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:5 mentions God raising a righteous Branch from David who will reign and execute justice. This messianic prophecy aligns with 2 Samuel 7:12-16 and is fulfilled in Christ as described in Luke 1:32-33 and Revelation 22:16.

questions.question: What name is given to the righteous Branch in Jeremiah 23?
questions.correctAnswer: THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:6 calls the coming King 'THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS,' highlighting His divine nature and role as source of righteousness, consistent with 1 Corinthians 1:30 and Isaiah 45:24-25 where God's righteousness is central.

questions.question: What is the difference in how the people will acknowledge God in the days to come, according to Jeremiah 23?
options: They will say, 'The LORD liveth, which brought up and led the seed of Israel out of the north country'
They will only remember the Exodus from Egypt
They will worship Baal instead of the LORD
They will reject all references to God's deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: They will say, 'The LORD liveth, which brought up and led the seed of Israel out of the north country'
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:7-8 contrasts old and new expressions of God's saving acts, emphasizing a future restoration from exile rather than just the Exodus, echoing Ezekiel 37:21-22 and Isaiah 43:6-7 about gathering Israel from all lands.

questions.question: What is Jeremiah's emotional response to the false prophets, as described in Jeremiah 23?
options: His heart is broken and he is like a drunken man
He is indifferent to their words
questions.correctAnswer: His heart is broken and he is like a drunken man
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:9 reveals the prophet's deep sorrow and distress over the false prophets’ corruption, similar to Ezekiel 21:7 and Isaiah 6:5 where confrontation with sin causes anguish.

questions.question: What moral condition of the land does Jeremiah 23 describe?
options: The land is full of adulterers and mourns because of swearing
The land is prosperous and blessed
The land is peaceful and just
The land is deserted by evildoers
questions.correctAnswer: The land is full of adulterers and mourns because of swearing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:10 describes the land’s corruption and moral decay, reflecting God's judgment, similar to Hosea 4:1-2 and Isaiah 1:4 where covenant unfaithfulness brings desolation.

questions.question: How does God describe the prophets and priests in His house in Jeremiah 23?
questions.correctAnswer: They are profane and wicked
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:11 declares that both prophets and priests are profane, indicating their failure to uphold holiness, which aligns with Micah 3:11 and Ezekiel 22:26 regarding corrupt leaders.

questions.question: What is the consequence for the false prophets who prophesy lies and cause God's people to err, according to Jeremiah 23?
options: They shall not profit the people at all
They shall be lifted up and honored
They shall be given new revelations
They shall be forgiven without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not profit the people at all
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:32 states that false prophets who lead people astray will gain nothing for the people, consistent with Deuteronomy 18:20-22 and Matthew 7:15-20 on false prophets' judgment.

questions.question: What metaphor does God use in Jeremiah 23 to describe His word?
options: Like a fire and a hammer that breaks the rock
Like a gentle breeze that soothes
Like a river that flows softly
questions.correctAnswer: Like a fire and a hammer that breaks the rock
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:29 compares God's word to fire and a hammer breaking rock, symbolizing its power to purify and break resistance, which parallels Hebrews 4:12 and Isaiah 55:10-11 about the potency of God's word.

questions.question: What attitude does Jeremiah 23 attribute to false prophets regarding their dreams?
options: They prophesy lies and deceit from their own hearts
They only interpret dreams given by God
questions.correctAnswer: They prophesy lies and deceit from their own hearts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:26-27 exposes false prophets as speaking deceit from their own hearts and causing people to forget God's name, echoing Ezekiel 13:2-3 and 2 Peter 2:1 about false teachers.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 23, what will happen to the city and people who pervert the words of the living God?
options: God will utterly forget and forsake them
They will be exalted above others
questions.correctAnswer: God will utterly forget and forsake them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:39-40 pronounces God's rejection and forsaking of those who pervert His words, consistent with Isaiah 1:28 and 2 Thessalonians 1:8-9 concerning judgment for disobedience.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 23 say about the relationship between God and His knowledge of His people?
options: God is both near and far and sees all things
God only sees what is done publicly
God can be hidden from in secret places
questions.correctAnswer: God is both near and far and sees all things
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:23-24 emphasizes God's omnipresence and omniscience, affirming He fills heaven and earth and nothing can be hidden from Him, paralleling Psalm 139:7-12 and Proverbs 15:3.

questions.question: What is God's instruction regarding the words 'the burden of the LORD' in Jeremiah 23?
options: Do not mention 'the burden of the LORD' anymore because the words have been perverted
Always proclaim 'the burden of the LORD' to the people
Use 'the burden of the LORD' only in times of peace
Replace 'the burden of the LORD' with dreams
questions.correctAnswer: Do not mention 'the burden of the LORD' anymore because the words have been perverted
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:36 instructs that the phrase 'the burden of the LORD' should no longer be used because the people have distorted God's words, similar to warnings in Ezekiel 13:10-16 about false prophecy.

questions.question: What role does Jeremiah 23 assign to true prophets in God's counsel?
options: They stand in God's counsel and turn people from evil
They prophesy from their own imagination
They remain silent and avoid responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: They stand in God's counsel and turn people from evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 23:22 explains that true prophets stand in God's counsel and call people to repentance, consistent with the role of prophets in Amos 3:7 and Acts 3:19 calling for turning from sin.
